situations.title: Claim Denied â€“ Wear & Tear
situations.summary: Request insurer's engineering report; supply roofer's statement proving sudden damage.
situations.details: When insurers deny claims citing 'wear and tear,' they must provide specific evidence. Request their engineering report and obtain a professional roofer's statement documenting sudden damage versus gradual deterioration.

situations.title: Lowball Estimate
situations.summary: Compare insurer vs contractor scope; list omitted items; request reinspection.
situations.details: Systematically compare the insurer's estimate with contractor estimates. Document all omitted items, code upgrades, and scope differences. Request a reinspection with your contractor present.

situations.title: No Response for 30+ Days
situations.summary: Send Notice of Delay citing statutory timelines (14/30 days).
situations.details: Most states require insurers to acknowledge claims within 14 days and provide coverage decisions within 30 days. Send a formal Notice of Delay citing your state's specific timeline requirements.

situations.title: Partial Payment
situations.summary: Summarize unpaid items; request written explanations.
situations.details: When insurers make partial payments, request written explanations for all unpaid items. Document the specific coverage decisions and challenge any improper exclusions.

situations.title: Depreciation Dispute
situations.summary: Ask for ACV vs RCV calculation; show repair invoices to release holdback.
situations.details: Understand the difference between Actual Cash Value (ACV) and Replacement Cost Value (RCV). Provide repair invoices to release depreciation holdbacks and maximize your settlement.

situations.title: Code Upgrade Denial
situations.summary: Cite ordinance/law coverage; provide building department requirements.
situations.details: Most policies include ordinance and law coverage for code upgrades. Obtain building department requirements and cite specific policy language supporting coverage for mandatory upgrades.

situations.title: Matching Issues
situations.summary: Document visible differences; cite matching coverage language.
situations.details: When insurers refuse to pay for matching materials, document visible differences and cite your policy's matching coverage language. This is often covered under 'consequential damage' provisions.

situations.title: Betterment Charges
situations.summary: Challenge as improper; request detailed breakdown of charges.
situations.details: Insurers cannot charge for 'betterment' unless the repair actually improves the property beyond pre-loss condition. Request detailed breakdowns and challenge improper betterment charges.

situations.title: Deductible Dispute
situations.summary: Verify deductible amount; check for multiple deductibles applied.
situations.details: Verify your deductible amount and ensure no multiple deductibles are being applied. Some policies have separate deductibles for different perils that may not apply to your claim.

situations.title: Scope Creep
situations.summary: Document additional damage discovered; request supplement.
situations.details: When additional damage is discovered during repairs, document everything and request a supplement. Insurers are obligated to pay for all damage caused by the covered peril.

situations.title: Emergency Services Denial
situations.summary: Cite emergency services coverage; provide contractor emergency rates.
situations.details: Most policies cover emergency services to prevent further damage. Document the emergency nature of the work and provide contractor emergency rates to justify higher costs.

situations.title: Contents Inventory Dispute
situations.summary: Provide detailed inventory; challenge depreciation rates.
situations.details: Provide detailed inventories with purchase dates and current values. Challenge excessive depreciation rates and request replacement cost for items less than 5 years old.

situations.title: Temporary Housing Denial
situations.summary: Cite ALE coverage; provide rental market analysis.
situations.details: Additional Living Expenses (ALE) coverage pays for temporary housing when your home is uninhabitable. Provide rental market analysis to justify reasonable costs.

situations.title: Expert Opinion Dispute
situations.summary: Request independent expert; challenge insurer's expert qualifications.
situations.details: You have the right to independent experts. Challenge the insurer's expert qualifications and request your own expert evaluation at the insurer's expense.

situations.title: Policy Limit Concerns
situations.summary: Review policy limits; request coverage analysis.
situations.details: Review your policy limits and request a detailed coverage analysis. Ensure all applicable coverage is being considered, including extended coverage and endorsements.

situations.title: Timeline Violations
situations.summary: Document all delays; cite state insurance regulations.
situations.details: Document all delays and cite specific state insurance regulations. Most states have strict timelines for claim handling that insurers must follow.

situations.title: Business Income Denial
situations.summary: Provide P&L statements; document revenue projections.
situations.details: Business income coverage requires detailed financial documentation. Provide profit and loss statements, tax returns, and revenue projections to establish your business income claim.

situations.title: Extra Expense Dispute
situations.summary: Document all extra expenses; justify necessity.
situations.details: Extra expense coverage pays for costs to minimize business interruption. Document all expenses and justify their necessity in maintaining business operations.

situations.title: Period of Restoration Dispute
situations.summary: Provide contractor timeline; challenge insurer's timeline.
situations.details: The period of restoration determines how long business income coverage applies. Provide contractor timelines and challenge any unrealistic restoration periods set by the insurer.

situations.title: Civil Authority Coverage
situations.summary: Cite civil authority orders; document business closures.
situations.details: Civil authority coverage applies when government orders prevent access to your business. Cite specific orders and document how they prevented business operations.

situations.title: Dependent Property Coverage
situations.summary: Document supplier/customer relationships; prove dependency.
situations.details: Dependent property coverage applies when your business depends on other properties. Document supplier and customer relationships to prove dependency.

situations.title: Extended Period of Indemnity
situations.summary: Document market conditions; justify extended coverage.
situations.details: Extended period of indemnity coverage applies when business takes longer to recover than expected. Document market conditions and justify why extended coverage is needed.

situations.title: Contingent Business Income
situations.summary: Document supplier/customer damage; prove business impact.
situations.details: Contingent business income coverage applies when suppliers or customers are damaged. Document the damage and prove how it impacts your business operations.

situations.title: Employee Wages Dispute
situations.summary: Provide payroll records; justify wage continuation.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include employee wages. Provide payroll records and justify why wage continuation is necessary for business recovery.

situations.title: Rent/Lease Disputes
situations.summary: Document lease obligations; prove continuing expenses.
situations.details: Business income coverage includes continuing lease obligations. Document lease terms and prove that rent payments continue during the restoration period.

situations.title: Utility Expenses
situations.summary: Document utility costs; justify continuing expenses.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include continuing utility expenses. Document utility costs and justify why these expenses continue during restoration.

situations.title: Professional Services
situations.summary: Document professional fees; justify necessity.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include professional services needed for business recovery. Document fees and justify their necessity for business operations.

situations.title: Marketing/Advertising
situations.summary: Document marketing costs; justify business recovery.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include marketing and advertising costs needed for business recovery. Document costs and justify their role in business recovery.

situations.title: Inventory Loss
situations.summary: Document inventory values; challenge depreciation.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include inventory losses. Document inventory values and challenge excessive depreciation rates applied by the insurer.

situations.title: Equipment Rental
situations.summary: Document rental costs; justify temporary equipment.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include equipment rental costs for temporary operations. Document rental costs and justify the necessity of temporary equipment.

situations.title: Relocation Expenses
situations.summary: Document relocation costs; justify temporary location.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include relocation expenses for temporary operations. Document costs and justify the necessity of a temporary location.

situations.title: Contract Cancellation
situations.summary: Document contract losses; prove business impact.
situations.details: Business income coverage may include losses from cancelled contracts. Document contract losses and prove how they impact business operations.

situations.title: Hurricane Damage Assessment
situations.summary: Document all hurricane damage; separate wind vs flood damage.
situations.details: Hurricane damage requires careful documentation to separate wind damage (covered) from flood damage (may require separate coverage). Document all damage immediately after the storm.

situations.title: Flood Coverage Dispute
situations.summary: Review flood policy; document flood vs wind damage.
situations.details: Flood damage requires separate flood insurance. Review your flood policy and carefully document what damage is from flooding versus wind to ensure proper coverage.

situations.title: Wildfire Damage
situations.summary: Document fire damage; separate smoke vs fire damage.
situations.details: Wildfire damage requires careful documentation of fire damage versus smoke damage. Both may be covered, but require different documentation approaches.

situations.title: Earthquake Damage
situations.summary: Document structural damage; separate earthquake vs other causes.
situations.details: Earthquake damage requires separate earthquake insurance. Document all structural damage and separate earthquake damage from other potential causes.

situations.title: Tornado Damage
situations.summary: Document wind damage; separate tornado vs other wind.
situations.details: Tornado damage is typically covered under windstorm coverage. Document all wind damage and separate tornado damage from other wind events.

situations.title: Hail Damage
situations.summary: Document hail damage; provide weather reports.
situations.details: Hail damage requires specific documentation including weather reports and damage photos. Document all hail damage immediately as it can be difficult to prove later.

situations.title: Ice Storm Damage
situations.summary: Document ice damage; separate ice vs other causes.
situations.details: Ice storm damage requires careful documentation to separate ice damage from other potential causes. Document all damage and provide weather reports.

situations.title: Blizzard Damage
situations.summary: Document snow/ice damage; separate weather vs other causes.
situations.details: Blizzard damage requires documentation of snow and ice damage. Separate weather-related damage from other potential causes and provide weather reports.

situations.title: Drought Damage
situations.summary: Document drought damage; separate drought vs other causes.
situations.details: Drought damage requires careful documentation to separate drought-related damage from other potential causes. Document all damage and provide weather reports.

situations.title: Heat Wave Damage
situations.summary: Document heat damage; separate heat vs other causes.
situations.details: Heat wave damage requires documentation of heat-related damage. Separate heat damage from other potential causes and provide weather reports.

situations.title: Severe Storm Damage
situations.summary: Document storm damage; separate storm vs other causes.
situations.details: Severe storm damage requires careful documentation to separate storm-related damage from other potential causes. Document all damage and provide weather reports.

situations.title: Lightning Damage
situations.summary: Document lightning damage; provide electrical damage evidence.
situations.details: Lightning damage requires specific documentation including electrical damage evidence. Document all electrical damage and provide evidence of lightning strikes.

situations.title: Power Outage Damage
situations.summary: Document power outage damage; separate power vs other causes.
situations.details: Power outage damage requires documentation of damage caused by power outages. Separate power-related damage from other potential causes.

situations.title: Water Damage from Storms
situations.summary: Document water damage; separate storm vs flood damage.
situations.details: Water damage from storms requires careful documentation to separate storm-related water damage from flood damage. Both may have different coverage requirements.

situations.title: Debris Removal
situations.summary: Document debris removal costs; justify necessity.
situations.details: Debris removal coverage pays for removing debris from covered damage. Document all debris removal costs and justify their necessity for property restoration.

situations.title: Emergency Repairs
situations.summary: Document emergency repairs; justify necessity.
situations.details: Emergency repair coverage pays for temporary repairs to prevent further damage. Document all emergency repairs and justify their necessity for property protection.
